summary: This is a court opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the defense's motion to exclude the government's expert witness, Dr. Lisa Rocchio, in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The court largely denies the motion, allowing Dr. Rocchio to testify on topics including grooming, trauma, and victim behavior, but excludes one specific opinion about 'grooming-by-proxy'.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein and participating in the sexual abuse of minors.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge who authored this opinion and order, presiding over the case.

persons.name: Lisa Rocchio
persons.context: Clinical psychologist and proposed government expert witness on topics including grooming, trauma, and victim behavior in cases of sexual abuse of minors.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the predator with whom Ghislaine Maxwell allegedly conspired to groom and sexually abuse minors.

connections.description: The government alleges Maxwell conspired with Epstein, a predator who groomed and sexually abused minors.
Dr. Rocchio is an expert witness for the prosecution in the criminal case against Maxwell.

events.title: Daubert Hearing
events.description: Court conducted a hearing to examine the admissibility of expert testimony from Dr. Lisa Rocchio.

events.title: Court Issues Opinion on Expert Testimony
events.description: Judge Nathan issued this opinion and order, largely denying the defense's motion to exclude Dr. Rocchio's testimony but excluding one specific opinion.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court ruled that Dr. Lisa Rocchio, an expert on trauma and sexual abuse, is qualified and her proposed testimony on grooming and victim behavior is largely admissible under the Daubert standard.

The court excluded one specific opinion from Dr. Rocchio: that the presence of a third party can facilitate grooming ('grooming-by-proxy'), finding it lacked sufficient support in the relevant literature.
The defense's motion to exclude Dr. Rocchio's testimony was based on arguments about reliability, relevance, and prejudicial effect, which the court largely rejected.
The opinion cites numerous prior cases from various circuits where similar expert testimony on grooming and trauma bonding has been admitted.
The government alleges Ghislaine Maxwell both participated in sexual abuse of minors and conspired with Jeffrey Epstein, who groomed and abused minors.
